name: GR-7 Formula One_EA
description:
A designer by the name of Robbie Grove created the GR-7 in the late 80's. There were only two made #55 "Bummers Bullet",and #96 "Blue Streak". Although not a winner the blue streak was a top qualifier in 1989 clocked at 242 mph. There is a coll mesh for this plane despite the fact the model is well under the 8000 cap for non use of coll mesh. 4598 poly tris





Enjoy

threadData.body:
I originally posted this thread in the project list page. So now I started this build thread in case anyone may be interested in following along with the design process.


I've decided to model this GR-7 Formula one racer. A designer by the name of Robbie Grove created this in the late 80's. There were only two made #55 "Bummers Bullet",and #96 "Blue Streak". Although not a winner the blue streak was a top qualifier in 1989 clocked at 242 mph. The only design info I can find on this one is that it has a high aspect ratio wing for turning stability. Also there's a pic of # 87 Madness (formerly #96)without it's cowling, and a four cylinder engine is clearly visible. Maybe someone could tell it's make just by looking. Also anyone who might be able to make a guess as to the airfoil would be a big help. Anyways its a racer just like the "little tony" found in G3 expansion pack 3. There are some differences though especially at the tail section. This is a very small full size aircraft and I'm not sure what size I should make the RF model. So i'm open to suggestions on that.

First day's progress

This is the end of the first days work on the GR-7. This the progress this far!

with wings

I went ahead with modeling the wings. Would've posted last night but Comcast went down in my area last night.

Six hours in

Around six hours into the project and the model itself is done. Pivots are set, naming done, and parenting. Time to export and set up some physics. I think I may scale this one up a bit. maybe a 50%. sounds big I know but the full scale is a very small single seat racer. 26 foot wing span. Unless someone can convince me otherwise.

Setback!

Well I thought i'd go a little further an proboolean the holes in the cowl for the exhaust. when I did it seemed to have deleted the fuse. I was zoomed in and hadn't noticed what had happened. then my video card crashed and scared me into a save. Needless to say I have to redo the fuse.

Fuselage redo

Well because of my own stupidity I had to redo the fuse, but after a couple more hours it's once again a complete model. One good thing came of it. I reduced the poly count by 474. Oh and the original had an extra set of polys to the rear of the canopy added making it too long. Oh well stuff happens.
Looks good Boof! Fast Progress too! Can't wait to fly this beauty.
Thanks I can't wait either. I'm setting up physics today and starting mapping to prep foe the color scheme

As for your airfoils, most of these modern high-speed racers use full symmetric airfoils that are fairly thin.  Without actually making measurements, I'd say start with 9-11% airfoils with 0% camber on the mains and NACA 0008 on the stabs and you'll be on the right track
Thanks I'll start there. I'll let you know how it goes

Well I believe I have this GR-7 model setup the way I like it in RF. I went with a NACA 0010-34 from root to tip. I added 1 degree of incidence to the main wing. I see some incidence in the photos. The engine I chose was the "pylon 1.60 2-stroke". Not sure if it's an engine thats default in RF or if it's imported with one of the many downloaded planes I have. It's turning a 18x12 Mejzlik carbon fiber narrow prop. Servo speed is .23 and all the servos are digital.It seems well balanced and the stall severity is set to 80% on all flight surfaces. I'm sure it's not the final configuration but for now it's a start. Here it is in temporary green for the test phase in RF. Next I think I will model a cockpit because it is currently only 4212 poly tri's> I think all said and done it will be bellow 10k.

Question - Do you have an engineering reason for overriding the stall?

For example, does the aircraft have some wing modifications that RF cannot simulate. If not leave those kinds of things alone. The only physics override you should consider is the frontal drag on fuselage/moving pod items that are not "rectangular" in their frontal aspect.

You recommended it!

Actually I was following a recommendation I read in a physics setup tutorial, you wrote I believe, stating that RF default setting of 0% for stall severity was non realistic and that even stable aircraft should have settings over 50%. and settings of closer to 100% or more for aerobatic planes. Has your stance changed on this and I missed that thread or did I misinterpret?

dhk79 posted on 7/05/2007
"A good catch from opjose is that the default Stall Severity for all airfoils is zero. This value make the stalls in G3 unrealistically gentle and makes certain aerobatic maneuvers nearly impossible. In playing around with the effect of this setting, we have determined that all airfoils should have at least 50% (even the most docile). Mid-lift airfoils that are commonly used in most sport models in the 70-80% range and low-lift airfoils found on 3D craft closer to 100%"

He's right there Doug. Honestly... I would set it up with closer to 90-95% myself. I reserve 50% for big bombers and 95-100% for jets. This would be my recommendation for the wings... The fuse is a different story. huh, then I guess you are both right.

Default Value:

Boof! Put it wherever you wish.

In my experience the "Stall Severity %" is as relevant as "Snap Roll Boost %". "Snap Roll Boost %" doesn't do squat! At least in the most recent version of RF. Maybe it's a remnant of previous versions.

By the way... Love the video of GB! Speaks volumes.

That old recommendation was based on G3 defaults being a bit unrealistic. I guess that with G4-G5, there really isn't any default any more, since it always bases the initial physics off of a plane that you choose. So you're probably right in that you have to do something with it by considering what type of plane it is. That being said, with the airfoils you are using (i.e. 0% camber = 0 aerodynamic lift) and on a racer the value should be very close to 100%.

I do stand by the adage that if you don't understand why you are making an adjustment, you probably shouldn't.

Doug! Since you mentioned it... The baseline model choice when importing the .kex file?

I have seen original models posted that are difficult if not impossible to re-edit the physics in any meaningfull manner. Then others that are very responsive.

I must assume that this has something to do with the base model chosen and it's associated physics?
All parameters are available to any plane.  But the closer the match you pick for the baseline, the less tweaking you'll need to do.

Yes, when you first import a KEX file RF asks you first what type of KEX it is (airplane, heli, or airport object) and then will ask you to choose an aircraft on which to base the physics.  So depending on what plane you choose, it is possible to get some really odd-ball values.  This is why I will usually just pick the top of the list (1903 Wright Flyer), delete everything, and start from scratch when setting up physics.

Yes! I understand your reasoning.

The only concern I have is wether or not the physics embeded in one baseline choice is the same as another choice. For example... A 3D model as opposed to the Wright Flyer (I will assume there is a mid-wing monoplane choice for 3D purposes).

Perhaps the default physics for the Wright Flyer is different than the 3D model. That is to say that 100% wing lift for one choice may be different than 100% wing lift of the other. I'm just using wing lift for example but that could easily apply to all parameters.

I can only surmise this based on my own edits.

If so I guess the KE guys would be the only people to know this.

Any thoughts?

If it still exists, there's probably useful info.

Flip, let's say that you and I both import the same Kex.  You pick a Cap to base the physics, and I pick an F-16 to base the physics.  You tweak the plane to fly accurately.  Then, you and I go line by line right down the list in the editor, and I duplicate everything exactly as you have it.  My plane would then be a carbon copy of your plane, and it would fly exactly the same way.  Where the physics originates is somewhat irrelevant.  It's the finished product that matters.

The only other thing I can say is based on my real world experience with flying RC, This plane has a semi-realistic feel. It by no means is perfect but a close approximation. When it boils down to it that's all that matters, don't you think? You can find flaws in any RF model if you look hard enough.

The physics tutorial is still valid.  The only thing that has changed since I wrote it has been RF.  The aerodynamic properties are still the same ones I studied in college thirty some-odd years ago.  The newer versions of RF seem to have improved the default stall behavior (and also reduced the over-all effect of that stall variable).  In G3 it was hard to get a plane to stall at all without cranking up the stall severity.  With G4/5 the severity can even be set to zero and the plane will still stall, but mushily (if that's a word).

You are also right in that the most important aspect is to make it feel right. I have several warbirds that will stall in a heartbeat if you let the speed get too low.

BTW in aerodynamic terms there is no such thing as a "tip-stall", it is just a stall and the fact one wing drops is due to that wing losing lift faster than the other.
I understand I was just using the familiar jargon associated with this aerodynamic phenomenon.

Mapping Done!

So the mapping is complete, and I found a way to make it perfectly symmetrical. Basically I only mapped the left side of the plane. Then simply copy and pasted the unwrap UV to the other half of the plane. Then in the UV edit screen selected the new side and mirrored over. Then scaled whole groups together. I'm sure other people must know this technique, but it's new to me.
Good Map! Looks really clean. Should be good for racing CS's.

General guidance for Normal Maps (also nown as Bump Maps) are that they are based on 256 shades of grey. Black being zero and white being 255. The neutral grey 128 is the mid point or a level surface. Everything darker than this is recessed and everything lighter is raised.

Map out your bumps and indentations on multi-layers, combine them, and then use the plugin to process.

Use the options shown for the plugin and save the result as your _N.TGA file. Just copy it into the ...\RealFlight G4\Vehicles\CustomModels\... directory for your aircraft and RF will take care of the rest.

Show both sides and canopy?

Could someone tell me how to get the "show both sides",and"canopy" prefixes to work? As the picture illustrates I am attempting to name multi sub objects in the material editor ~SBS,and~CANOPY. Neither will work in RF. How far off am I?

I do not think RF will recognise sub-object materials. Do the exact same thing as a primary material and the names will work.

BTW there is also an ~ALPHA material to use transparency without the Show-Both-Sides that is also part of ~CANOPY.

Rf does uderstand the sub-object materials. My canopy is transparent which is the first sub object material in the pic. I'm still confused how to use this naming convention since RF will only accept oone bitmap for a model. Can you expand on your explaination. Sorry

dhk79 said:
I do not think RF will recognise sub-object materials. Do the exact same thing as a primary material and the names will work.

BTW there is also an ~ALPHA material to use transparency without the Show-Both-Sides that is also part of ~CANOPY.
Click to expand...
Ok I see from the picture. Question answered. Thanks again

That's easy.  You can have as many materials as you like, but only one bitmap.  If you look at the example I posted, you'll see three materials that use the same map.  Each material can therefore have different reflectivity or use different reserved names, so that they'll behave differently in RF.

dhk79 said:
That's easy. You can have as many materials as you like, but only one bitmap. If you look at the example I posted, you'll see three materials that use the same map. Each material can therefore have different reflectivity or use different reserved names, so that they'll behave differently in RF.
Click to expand...
Thats a game changer for me anyways. That will be much easier.

I usually use several on each model. I'll normally have a default material that has a slight reflectivity (similar to Monocote), a flat or dull version for things I don't want any gloss on (i.e. rubber parts), sometimes I'll also have a shiny material. Then of course there are ~SBS, ~ALPHA, and ~CANOPY for their special uses. Note use ~SBS & ~CANOPY sparingly and only on parts that need them as they double the rendering load of your graphics card.

ViennaLex also posted a MAX plugin that will allow you to preview the way RF processes the maps. It works pretty well, but you have to unassign the Normal and Spectral maps before you export a KEX file.

http://www.knifeedge.com/forums/showpost.php?p=174289&postcount=26

No, that's only for additional colorschemes. When making an EA the original TGA files go in the same aircraft's directory as the KEX file.

Boof69 said:
the export fails and says "too many bitmap materials. please limit to 1". I reapply the original .TGA and it exports just fine. What am I missing?
Click to expand...
You've got an additional bitmap assigned to a material.

Open the menu option Files/Asset Tracking... and make sure ther is only one entry under Map / Shaders and that it is pointing to your TGA file. If there is more than one entry, highlight each additional line and browse to your TGA file to merge it with the one map line you want.

Physics help

This one is for DHK79. Would you mind helping out on this one? I am going crazy trying to get the physics just right. As it stands it's fairly balanced and the speed is good. The main thing I have a problem with is the elevator at full extension,(10 degrees), is causing a hard left roll. I decrease the deflection to 8 degrees the roll goes away completely,but then the elevator is ineffective at slow or landing speeds. I'm a bit frustrated. So if you get a chance.... Thanks

There's actually been recent discussion on this.  In my opinion, leave it at 10 degrees, and don't use full elevator in a loop.  Just like to much turning can jacknife a semi, you wouldn't want to take away the ability to turn sharply.  You don't have to use all the elevator all the time.  I would bet it's the same way with full scale aerobatic planes.

OK, here's what I see right off the bat from just looking at the physics.

1) Your wing loading is too high. A high performance aircraft such as this should have a wing loading of 24-26 oz/ft^2 and yours is a tad over 34 oz/ft^2. This means the plane is too heavy.

2) The airframe is also over-powered, but that is probably due in part to #1.

3) Your canopy does not seem to be included in the physics model. Either make it part of the fuselage or add it as another fuselage component.

4) Fuselage frontal drag should be around 85% due to the shape of the fuse.

5) Elevator physics does not match the 3D model's surface area.

6) You are going to need a CG override because the vertical tail is in the physics model twice. Once as part of the Fuselage and then as itself. This will be in the +Y direction (not in the Z that you currently have). This will also effect the flight dynamics of the fuselage. You would be better off in the long run, just to cut off the end of the fuselage as a seperate part and not have it all as one (even though it is molded that way in real-life).

Now to go fly it.

After first flight test:

The plane is too fast, which is causing most of your handling problems at full throttle. The full scale aircraft maxes out at about 240 MPH. Yours is a bit less than a quarter scale, which should put the max speed at around 60 MPH. Since it's RC plane you can probably stretch that a bit, but more than doubling it is out of the question.

By eye-ball, I'd say the CG is a little too far forward but fix the other problems first and then work on the CG and thrust vectors.

Doug

name: Lindberg's Lockheed Sirius_EA
description:
This is the lockheed Sirius owned and flown by Charles A. Lindbergh.
This model has a 96" wing span and measures 60" nose to tail. It's quite nimble as was the RL aircraft. Powered by a Fuji Imvac BT-50SB 46.5cc turning a 18"x12 prop.




Many cameras one in each cockppit and one above the tail.
the cockpit cams move with the flaps knob
Anyone interested in doing a CS for this one PM me and I'll send you a template

Thanks to rcplanefubar and dhk79 for the 9cylinder radial engine generously posted in the parts repository.

History..
Built by the Lockheed company in 1930 the Sirius is the wheeled predecessor to Charles A. Lindbergh's Float plane nicknamed the "Tingmissartog". Which means "One who flies like big bird" in the Inuit language. Originaly named the "Explorer" and built for Harold Bromley in hopes to win th Tokyo Ashi prize of $25,000 for the first trans pacific flight between Japan and America. Although during takeoff over filled fuel tanks spilled into Harolds eyes blinding him and causing a crash. A second attempt at building the Explorer failed. So a third was made but now incorporating changes requested by Lindbergh including the name change to "Sirius". Harold never was succesfull in his attempts some of which didn't include the Lockheed company.




Enjoy

threadData.body:
This Thread will chronicle the process of modeling,mapping,and physics for two models.
The first is a plane dubbed the "Chester Goon". A 1930's AirRacer named from characters in the Popeye cartoons. The engine was a straight six Menasco Buccaneer. This long nosed aircraft looks very sleek and streamlined but the tiny manually retracted landing gear give it a ungainly appearance. I intend to be a bit more detailed with the actual model this time. With details such as louvers in the cowling and a sliding canopy to name a few.
The second is a plane suggested in another thread by Twoeleven.
The Lockheed-Sirrus was an aircraft built by Jack Northrop and Gerald Vultee while engineers for Lockheed in 1929 at the request of Charles Lindbergh. Lindbergh and his wife later used this plane to fly to the far east. Powered by a 680 HP Wright R-1820 The Sirrus was capable of flying 975 at a cruising speed of 150 miles per hour.
These planes will be built part for part. Meaning when part from each is complete I will post them to this thread together. In the end both will be posted to the swaps the same day.

Dual Build Thread

A series of really well modeled and built Golden Age 1930's air racers would be great for RF. Maybe you can add the "Miles Atwood Special" and "Miss LosAngeles", the" Jeep", may be Ben Howard's "Ike" or "Mike" or maybe "Pete",maybe a "Turner Special" or a "Keith Rider R-3, just to name a few of the great names in Air Racing during the Pre War Years.

Maybe you can add the "Miles Atwood Special" and "Miss LosAngeles", the" Jeep", may be Ben Howard's "Ike" or "Mike" or maybe "Pete",maybe a "Turner Special" or a "Keith Rider R-3, just to name a few of the great names in Air Racing during the Pre War Years.
Click to expand...
That may be a possibility since I really like the looks of these old planes.

Update!

I am still hard at work on these two planes. I am Almost done with the Goon's fuselage, and will be starting on the Lockheed Sirrus fuse later today, and hope to post screenies of both fuselages first thing tomorrow. Had an endless stream of visitors the past couple of days which has kept me from getting these models going.

Some Progress!

Well had some time to myself today, so I thought I'd Get the two fuselages done today. When I say done I mean "the outer fuse and wing stubs". You may notice the louvers on the Goon. I decided to model those rather than put them in the bump map. They are very deep and are a prominent part of the aircraft. As the Goon stands now I'm at 3,357 poly's with flight surfaces, cockpit details, and gear left to go. I should still come in under 10,000 if I optimize the model before export. The Lockheed Sirrus is at 2650 with the same amount left to model. So there you have it- with 9 hours in part no.1 is complete.
There looking relay good already keep up the great work

Day Two

Thanks Spot242,
Day two is down and I have completed the basic form of these two airplanes. They now have their respective fuselage,flight surfaces,and control surfaces. Now I just have to model the gear and details. Even with the new model work I'm only at 4,283 polys on the Goon. I went over the model and got rid of some unneeded edge loops. I'm a bit higher with the Sirrus but thats due to the addition of "The classic 9 cylinder engine" I borrowed from the repository. The sirrus now sits at 7,711 polys. I will repay the repository with a part soon.
Dang you're fast. You're ripping through these planes!
I put the overnight hours in too. I'm kinda addicted!
It's always the overnight hours...
What time is your bedtime, pig?  Aren't you in Eastern Time Zone?

Also, saw a few pictures of it on floats! Looks beautiful so I thought I'd drop this off so you may have it, you know, for future reference...

Texture mapping

Twoeleven,
This is the texture map for the Lockheed Sirius. If you could let me know if you notice anything in these pics that I could do to improve the final draft.

How much fun must it be to roll something like that out of a hanger on a warm summer afternoon? Pre-flight the thing, climb in, and set out for a low and slow(er) late afternoon cruise...One day.

Looking very paint-friendly. My input is this, try to keep everything in scale to it's relative part, right fuse to left fuse, etc., which you have done. Occupy vast sections of the texture map with the surfaces that will most likely get graphics and/or detailed paint like nose art. Take up little bits of real estate with things like insides of control surfaces, small bits that will be one color. Arrange the map so that text can go on in-line with either 90 or 180 degrees when possible. All of this stuff looks like you have it in there.

Last thought, arrange the texture map in the most efficient manner possible, making the detailed areas large, but arranged well to maximaize space. Things like a detailed dash panel and/or cockpit interior will require an increased proportion of the texture map, but will look fantastic in-sim, particularly in G5 just in case someone wants to fly first person.

So, I would arrange things to make space for that, see attached as an example, I've got some room on my rearranged version of your texture map to make the dash panel and some other things larger, to allow for greater detail at the same resolution. All of your parts are on this example, the exact same size as on your map. I also understand you can map some areas at higher resolution on the same map, but simply making those areas larger works well, too.

All of these things are just a painter's selfish wants, ultimately, it is all up to you and we will willingly work with what is in there.

My opinion is you are very much on the right track, it looks great.

Griff
twoeleven

The final arrangement is a bit like a game of tetris. I had thought that it was important to keep elements of the model together in the diffuse map, such as wheel pant halves, wing orientation, tail section parts, etc. Is arranging the individual pieces to optimize for space rather than part proximity a shared opinion by other CSers? If so than I will definitely arrange this and future maps in this manner. I just want other artists to be able to create color schemes easily. This is by no means an argument just clarification

I agree. I think I went into the mindset of "maximum efficiency" with little regard for parts groupings...Hehe. My arrangement will be slightly harder to locate everything for the next painter, but the dash could sure look intense!

A balance of the two may be a reasonable position.

Griff
twoeleven
I will arrange this one to your liking if you will do the CS.

Deal. But I do like the point you brought up...More people will be likely to paint it if it has a "user friendly" map, so no need to go crazy, just make the dash a bit bigger and I think you have a winner. Is it 4096 x 4096 by chance....?

Griff
twoeleven

Thats the size I always use. I would have to make a dash since this was more of an RC version. In the plans you provided there is merely a box that runs thru both cockpits. Do you think it would be better with a full modeled cockpit? If so do you have any reference images I could use for this?

why does the fuse look so ....fat/short on the map?
wont that cause some serious stretching issues?
just does not seem to match the model in the 3d program

Would you like my two cents?

You're getting it anyway!!

I think that mapping the model is the transition between making the 3D model, and coloring the 3D model. The model obviously has to be mapped with the initial colorscheme in mind. I'm referring to stretched areas etc., but I think you know that. I believe, even as a modeler, that a model must be mapped the way the CS guy doing the initial scheme wants it to be mapped. If the modeler and the CS guy are the same person, then that's a no brainer. I don't believe, as griff suggested, that the CS guy must deal with the map as it is. I've had many conversations with the Maj., between each of my models, discussing what works and what doesn't work for him. I feel I owe it to him to map it as he likes it mapped. It makes his job easier that way. If I'm not willing to color my own planes (which is presently true), I feel obligated to make coloring easy for him. That said, I am asking him less each model how he wants it mapped, just from learning what he likes from experience.

Ooops, forgot about those plans...I would say keep it an RC plane, but just have an arch under the windscreen for instruments. As in a scale or semi-scale RC plane, the builder would apply either a faux panel or decals to that surface. I don't think it needs to be a full scale cockpit, per se, but a place for some instruments stays within the spirit of an RC model.




Not sure if you were sirius (ha) about doing the float version, but I found this as a great reference in case you do, float 3-views:

Quite the opposite, I believe. What you are seeing is more of the top and bottom of the fuse than we are used to seeing. It isnt just a pixel or two stretching across the top and bottom areas. As it is an unwrap, this will make it appear taller than it is, as the top and bottom can be painted with less distortion, and then rewrapped around the 3D mesh by RF. Check his UV preview renders, no box looks too stretched at all, looks great, I think.

Griff
twoeleven

why does the fuse look so ....fat/short on the map?

just does not seem to match the model in the 3d program
Click to expand...
It looks fat because of the effect of unwrapping a cylinder, making it taller than the 3d model. It's mapped so the grid squares are equal to each other so as to minimize stretching not cause it.

Maj., looks the the canopy on the map for the Art-Tech Diamond 2500. I mapped it by unfolding it, as well. It's a small piece, with a regular shape, but the shape on the map is different than the shape on the model. (But not really) I mapped it the same way as the part you are talking about. There is zero distortion on it, whereas if I mapped it the way you expected, the corners were distorted.

One thing I do in Wings that must be possible in Max is this: let's say I have a cockpit that I have loop it out of the fuselage. In the geometry editor, I'll select the entire cockpit, which is then, in turn, selected on the map as well. I'll move all the cockpit pieces to a different part of the UV window, and then I'll arrange the all into a pattern, square, rectangle, whatever.  I'll select the landing gear and the wheels, and arrange them all together, as well. Then when it's time to place them on the map, I move groups of objects around wherever possible into the final position.

Maj., I don't think you'll ever run out of work!

Update

Currently Twoeleven is in process of making the CS for the Sirius. While I am working on the CS and physics for the Chester Goon, and the physics for the Sirius. I don't really have any visual changes on either model so therefore no pics to post. But they are coming along never the less.

Here are the beginnings of the Sirius CS, seriously.

From Smithsonian: "Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife, Anne Morrow Lindbergh, purchased this Lockheed Sirius airplane in 1929 for $22,825. Designed by Gerald Vultee and Jack Northrop, the Sirius was a low-wing monoplane with the same monocoque (molded shell) fuselage as the popular Lockheed Vega. Originally an open-cockpit landplane, the Lindberghs' Sirius was modified with a sliding canopy and Edo floats for their two overwater journeys in 1931 and 1933.

The Lindberghs set a coast-to-coast speed record in the Sirius on April 20, 1930, but its most significant flights were in 1931 and 1933. In 1931 the Lindberghs flew to the Orient, proving the viability of traveling from the West to the Far East via the Great Circle route to the North. In 1933 they flew survey flights across the North and South Atlantic to gather information for planning commercial air routes. During their 1933 trip a Greenland Eskimo boy gave the Sirius its nickname: "Tingmissartoq"-"One who flies like a big bird.""

Just a start...

Proper renderings in 3ds Max can really make a model look it's best (the old Ricky Delton) was best at his renderings in Max.....his finished models looked identical to pictures of the real model. Part of what I'm trying to say is that I won't feel like somebody hates me or doesn't appreciate me just because they critcize me.  I think that would go a long way for many members here.  If somebody mentions a flaw in a model I'm building, and I get what they are talking about, I'll fix the problem, maybe.  That doesn't mean that I'll fix anything someone mentions.  Sometimes I may feel he is in error, or that it's too minor to change.  Anybody can say anything they want to about my models.  Most of it would go in one ear and out the other.  But, depending on who you are, I may take what you say to heart, and try to improve the model or my process.  Person A could tell me my model sucks, and I couldn't care less about his opinion.  Person B could tell me my model sucks, and he'll have my attention.  Even if he told me it was an awful model, I wouldn't think less of him or assume he hates me.  I would listen to him, and take his advice to heart.  Not because I'm trying to impress him or anyone else, but because I know he knows what he's talking about.  Many of you, including you, Boof, have helped me to become a better modeler.  For that I am grateful.

To be honest I did and do it for visual impact, and I personally don't use quality renders for error checking. Let's just file it under a nice touch. I may save up a Saturday morning in hopes to catch someone to shoot video and another to give me a launch. The wife has no interest in the hobby so its a real stretch to ask her to come to the field on a date and a sitter watch the kids.

So.. I can't wait for a detailed description of the maiden.

name: Beck-Mahoney Sorceress_EA
description:
The Beck-Mahoney Sorceress. The first biplane to break 200mph in competition and won the most races than any other in her class. The Sorceress was the state of the art in the 70's and 80's and now sits in the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum.




Turn on "normal maps" to see a fully bumped instrument panel, moving canopy, fully modeled cockpit, and fully animated steering gear. Powered by O.S. 120 ax turning a 14x10 prop. Very good low end torque for high alpha flight and torque rolling. Agile in high rates fun to fly. Canopy is on 6 (knob). This is a 1/4 scale model. This is my first real color scheme utilizing all three map types. Look close at the highlights to see the metal fiber look.
This model has 3 4096x4096 tga files associated. If you experience problems loading this model follow these instructions.
1. Pick a Photofield
2. Import the rfx
3. Restart the Sim
4. Load the model
If problems persist PM me for a zip file with .dds files




Enjoy

I saw the plane at the Smithsonian yesterday... I thought it was the same one you were modeling here... It is sweet.

You do know the story about the hole in the canopy? (you have modeled it too large, BTW)... There were requirements for this class of airplane that specified the bi-plane to have to interplane struts and an open cockpit. Struts etc would have required wire rigging (with associated drag), so the designer made cantilever wings and added a false non-structural strut at the end of the wing.

To meet the open cockpit requirement, he left a hole in the canopy just large enough for the pilots helmet to fill when he was in the aircraft. Filling the hole made the aircraft much more aerodynamic and was rather a cheat to meet the class requirements. It worked and he won many races.

Yes I was aware of the story it's all very interesting. In what way is the canopy modeled too large? These are the reference pics and 3 view I modeled from and I can assure you it's the same exact size as whats drawn.

I see what you are saying... think about a man's head...in a helmet. Will the helmet fill the hole in your canopy? I thought your opening was a bit large for that.

I can get you a closeup picture if you really want...it will take a week or two.

Is it at all possible to see the left side of her? If so that would be a big help. Thanks for the offer 12oclockhigh

Tonight's progress includes all the decals I could see in my reference pics an allot of work on the cockpit. The instrument panel isn't finished by any means but it's getting there. All of the lettering on this one I had to do by hand since no font I looked at was a match. Still didn't start the normal.tga yet. I figured that's best left until the end. I'm learning allot on this CS.

So after allot of hair pullin' and with help from a couple a guys (you know who you are) I finally got the Glass look I was hoping for. Plus the gauges have a nice glass look too. Thanks for the help everyone. Here's some pics.
These are a few shots taken consecutively to show some of the glass effects being applied in the cockpit.
I finished up with the C-mesh this morning which gives me a final count of 12556. I'm happy with that number. I don't think I could get it much lower.
Started putting in some bump tonight. Just a start but I think I'll take my time and deck this one out.
Looking great. I look forward to flying it.
I think you'll like the physics on this one. It's really the best one I've done yet in all aspects. That is to say the things I've done myself.
Had some time today to get more done on the cockpit. I decided to put in rudder pedals. Also settled on the interior materials and colors. Which included moving all the glass onto the maps.
Who are you talking to?

Just a few hours left mainly to tweak color for the rivets and panels. Plus go over the final physics. Overall this one has been a real learning experience. I thoroughly enjoyed the CS process. It takes some real organizational skills to keep track of three TGAs each with a whole lot of layers. I'm thinking I'll post this one Tuesday unless I decide to add something.

Sorceress is posted!

threadData.body:
I found another really neat flying wing model, Mike Oser's Dagger. Here is the note he sent me:

Subject: Re: Dagger Plans

Hi Andy,

I think that would be fun. I'm an avid RealFlight guy myself. I have
Autocad version 2000 format files if that will help. Just for grins I
attached a few pics of the complete model. It flys fantastic!

Let me know if the autocad (or dxf) files will help, or if there is
anything else I can do. Perhaps I can help tweak the flight model to
help it fly like the real thing.

The actual plane has only 7-8 flights on it, but it flies very fast,
very slow, handles just like any plane, but turns the squarest corner
you've ever seen. The model is a blast to fly, so maybe we can make a
sim model that's fun too.

Cheers,
Mike

Dagger flying video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5fCO8tf91qc

About the black Dagger:
Actually, all I had at the time was the raw balsa fuselage sitting on the table. I was photoshopping to see what some color schemes might look like. The wings and markings were totally faked in. And yes, all I did was take a negative image of one of the color schemes to see what a black version would look like. So, yes, there is only one.

About the modeling:

Howdy Gents, Mike Oser here.

First let me say that this is just too cool and that you are doing a fantastic job. I watched postings on this site till late last night and gave up keeping up! The model looks great and just like the RC version.

If there is anything I can do to assist just ask, and I'll get the 3-view photos to you ASAP.

Here is some info about the final build version if it helps...

I moved the front fuselage transition from square to the round spinner plate about 3 inches back behind the firewall on the top corners (less on the bottom) than indicated on the plans. I also increased the corner radius. So the front fuselage looks more streamlined than shown in the plans and blends smoothly with the spinner. See attached photos.

Also note that this is one of the only flying wings in the world that flys with no reflex on the elevons. They are set perfectly in line with the wing cord. Low rates are +/-1/4 inch, high is +/- 3/8.

Just FYI. Top speed was clocked at 118 mph with a sport prop(!). Landing speed is about 10 mph. Handles very smoothly and is not overly pitch sensitive like some flying wings. However, if you set high rates and jerk the stick back it will simply rotate 90 degrees instantly. After I added the wing fences it will no longer stall, just mushes down with about a 10+ deg angle of attack.

Quite fun. Can't wait to try your RealFlight Model!

Mike

I still need the close up on the pilot head and cockpit, wet flying weight and approx wing loading if you know it, Is the CG the same in the real world model as on the plans? As for the 3-view it won't be necessary due to the detail on the plans and simplicity of the model. Dhk79 has offered to do the physics. This should make for a nice flyer. Dhk79 will have the model tonight and I will start mapping today. Abaser will handle the CS so the Dagger will have life soon.
I shoulda spoke up. I think I coulda handled that CS!!

I'll get the pilot and cockpit photos when I get home from work in a couple hours. I thought you might want the 3view photos to use as texture maps, or as a guide for painting.

Dry weight is 5.63 lbs, wet weight is 6.29 lbs (full 12 oz tank). The fuel tank is on the CG, so there is no weight shift as fuel is burned (if you need that sort of detail).

Wing area is 700 sq.in, so the wing loading is 18.53 oz/sq.ft dry, 20.7 oz/sq.ft wet.

CG is as shown on the plans. Note that the main landing gear location on the plans is correct and is further back than on the prototype photos.

Mike

Yes, the main struts are airfoiled, about 1 inch wide and 1/4 thick. The landing gear is raked back in the photos, but this is only because I needed to move the wheels farther back after initial flight test. This has been corrected in the plans, so you should show the struts vertical.

And I did add fuselage strakes/fins under the cockpit (ala Mirage 2000). These, along with the wing fences greatly increased slow speed handling by directing airflow over the vertical fin/rudder at high angles of attack.

Mike
All of those details I will be sure to add to the finished product. I enjoyed modeling this one. Did you design the Dagger or just build it?
The pilot head is finished and I baked the color in to avoid mapping it.

Dagger Design

The Dagger is a totally home grown design and build. The wing airfoils are very unique and contribute to both high speed and very slow speed handling. I couldn't find anything close to this off the shelf or even from plans so I designed from scratch. I'm an engineer, and ex aero guy, so this is what I do for fun.

This was a small prototype to test the concept. The picture shows a photoshopped picture of a much larger and more jet like version that will probably come next. It will still have a conventional tractor glow engine.

Mike

what you're seeing is referred to as Ghosting

it is the the information from the _s.tga left over from the old CS

no pun intended ......... but to fix that you need to correct the _.stga to reflect your changes

you'll find it in the same folder that your reg. .("classic") tga is in

-s.tga work on a gray scale
a very light gray will give a mirror like appearance to your model

a black or very dark gray will give it a more flat appearance
search the forum............there are several threads that deal with this subject

Exponential

Can anyone tell me how to adjust the exponential in the flight model? In the Dagger it is listed as always on with no options to change the value of the exponentail. I'd like to reduce the amount of exponential a bit as it hits the steep part of the curve at landing making it too sensitive to flare out smoothly.

Thanks, Mike
Click on the output channel and the expo adjustments will show up.

Thanks. I must have jumped right into the "Expo When" thinking that's where it would be and missed it altogether. I'm learnin'.
Mike

Updated Dagger

Gents,

I have spent quite some time making adjustments to the Dagger flight model. What I hope is that those who are considering building the RC version will try this out and be convinced it will be a fun plane to build and fly. I have uploaded the updated AV file. This has a highly refined flight model that, as far as I can tell, takes off, lands, and flies exactly like the RC version.

In addition, and again with the desire for realism, I slightly adjusted abaser's original CS to more closely match the real thing by lightening the yellow and reducing the reflectivity. I included this updated CS, as well as a dark blue version of the same CS made by Andy.

If you would, please check that these files import properly and that the plane flies OK in RealFlight. Note that you should takeoff and land in low rates, which I set as swtich down.

If you find this works OK, please post the AV and CS files on the share site, with due credit to those involved.

I also include a recording and one cool screenshot.

name: AT-802(FireBoss)_EA
description:
The Air Tractor AT-802AF (Fire Boss)

Controls:
Water release_ on channel 5 (dual rates)
Cockpit doors_ on channel 8 down or away position
Windshield wiper_on channel 8 up or close position
Retracts_on channel 7 (Smoke/Retract)
Flaps_on channel 6 (knob)

Features:
Moving Control suface armatures under wings
Moving Rudder pedals and linkage
Moving Throttle and Joystick
Headlights
Wingtip flood lights
Nav lights
Strobe light
Glowing exhaust pipes

The physics for this model were scrutinized by a real world pilot of this aircraft (Jim Anderson) and approved as realistic for scale flight.
For a water take-off a little pressure on the elevator is required also ample room.

If your interested in creating a CS for this model follow this for a master CS template and raw normals .psd

History:
The Air Tractor AT-802AF meaning it's the AT-802 model (A) for single seat cockpit and (F) meaning fire gate equipped. The AT-802 line are the worlds largst single engine aircraft. Mainly used in the agricultural industry but also used in fire fighting. Powered by a pratt and whittney PT6A-65AG turbine engine (the only non military aircraft allowed to use) turning a constant speed 5 blade reversable pitch prop. Cruising speed is 191 mph (307 kph) but the working speed is 130-160 mph or 209-257 kph.




Enjoy

wing Tips

While you guys go around and around, I d thought I provide some useful information. As Boof69 noticed on the wing tips, the group of planes did display two different types of tips. The older tip is rounder from front to back. The other tip is a newer and preferred one. It is to help the air stay more in control ( smaller vortex ) behind the tips of the wing. I did not read this on any tractor sight but the same tips are used on the Scouts from American champion company. I also talked to a pilot who flew a Citabria and an air tractor while on leave last year. He told me the tips smaller vortex keeps the spray of chemicals in a straight line for a even spray across the spray bar.

I have even see another tip ( Pic 3 )that is rounder along the top edge and all most flat on the bottom and flat on it's side. I believe it is the oldest tip. It's nav light are farther forward. I took these picture in Alabama while talking to the pilots and owners. The guy had some of the biplanes Bob cats as well. I got some nice detail pictures of all the wheels, struts, control surfaces that most people don't take pictures of. If you feel like making that version too.
I went with example 2. It took allot of tweaking to get the geometry right.

Any geometry that is hidden i.e. (the back and bottom of the seat, the ends of each cylinder connecting the floats to the air frame) is deleted. Also cylinders that have a small diameter are reduced to 6 sided. Long flat surfaces with no change in angle will generally have no edge loops in the middle. I don't use spheres or hemispheres hardly ever due to their tenancy to eat up polys. I instead use bump an CS to accomplish the look. Here are some screens of my geometry if it helps.

I can't wait to see how your model behaves on the water.  The one I created had weird float tendancies.  I figure I never refined my model but still, I never cared how my model reacted.  I always had to let ot take off on it's own--too much drag when pulling back on the stick.  My flaps were incorrect too.  LOL.

I haven't started in with the water physics yet but I do see the same tenancies you noticed. I have to let her rise on her own. If I fight it it seems as if there is a water tension that needs to be over come and when the floats break the surface she rolls hard left. It may be the dualies dragging in the water and need to be raised a bit more. I don't know.

I figured out the deal with the floats. The higher the displacement value percentage the more buoyant a given object will be. A value of 500 will put the floats right up on top of the water. The real problem was the the big set of dualies setting in the water under the floats. I raised the displacement value and it helped quite a bit. The other important value was flooded displacement percentage. By default objects other than floats are given a value of 80. Which means it will take on water. 4 water logged tires hanging under the floats wasn't helping. With those changes the water behavior is normal. Now that the ground and water handling are  under control I can focus on flight. Went back into max and modeled more detail. Roll cage in the cockpit, throttle, seat belts, cleats on the floats, and the hopper top filler hardware.

~CS_BULB Object question

Does any one know off hand what the maximum amount of time I can set the NUP_OnPeriodSec for a ~CS_BULB? Also can someone explain what the NUP_OffsetSec value controls. I thought that if I set this value differently between two individual lights that they would turn on and off alternately but this doesn't seem to be the case. The only clear information given is from nemo uk and the post only describes syntax. No definitions were given. My purpose is to have the flood lights under each wingtip stay on for the maximum amount of time and it to be off for the minimum amount. I know that I could make them a glow object but the lights bulb geometry wouldn't show during the day, and I want to avoid doubling the geometry. Any help?
I'm not sure what the max is, but the offset is so that you can sequence multiple flashers (like on the amusement park).  Using the bulb object does not double geometry, it is your geometry.
Can you expand on the idea of sequencing Doug?

One light gets defined to be on for two seconds then off for two with no offset, then on the second light you do the same but with a two second offset.  The second light will then not start it's "on" sequence until the offset expires.  In this manner your two lights will alternate.
Is the correct syntax NUP_OffsetSEC=, or NUP_DelaySEC= ?

I'm pretty sure it's the first one, but would have to look it up to confirm.

EDIT: Yep, checking my notes:
~CS_BULB_ objects are visible both in daylight and night.
~CS_GLOW_ objects are only visible at night.

NUP_OffPeriodSEC=
NUP_OnPeriodSEC=
NUP_OffsetSEC=
Thank you Doug. Big help as always.

NUP_DelaySEC= is used for the 3ds2kexbeta converter,
NUP_OffsetSEC=is for Max Users.
There are subtle differences between the converter & Max Plug-in.
Under carriage NUP's differ with the Converter from the tutorials,which are specifically for Max.
ReadMe in converter gives the right NUP's for Non-Max Users.

The only thing left is the CS. This one won't be for everyone because of the high poly count. Like I said initially I didn't worry about poly count. If you want to fly an AT and you have a slower computer you can find one HERE. It's pplace's AT402. The file size is very small.

In setting up the physics for this one I've made some assumptions and assertions based on the limited video I have found. It appears to me that the AT-802 has good pitch agility due to the nap of the earth flying ability it displays in videos. I have never seen this with my own eyes so any confirmation would help. I wouldn't imagine the full size aircraft wouldn't have any acrobatic ability's but due to all the vertical wings around the model knife edge flight is possible. Knifeedge, I cant say, but I have seen them close to 45 degrees inverted turning around at the edge of the fields. When they started using the turbines around here, at the end of the fields, they would pullstraight up and stall turn it and straight back down. That practice was cut out after farmers started complaing about streaking in the fields due to differing airspeeds across the fields due to coming down out of the turns. Watching them spray back then was alot of fun.

It is hard to taxi in to position but I think this is due to to the nature of turboprops. Spooling up the engine to spin up the prop. By time the prop is going the rpms are too high and your going to fast. Slow taxi is almost impossible. No brakes are applied on the swaps version.


Unless there is something I don't know about the brake setup in RF it seems as if I apply any useful amount of brakes a noticeable drag effect happens. This setup works fine with my YF-23 because of the high power to weight ratio. The engine just over powers the brakes, but with the Fire Boss the lower power of the turbo prop makes this drawback more noticeable. I would prefer a good braking setup but the drag takes away from the scale power feel I was going for. I settled on the lesser of the two evils.

Help on taxi

I was wondering the same thing about the wheel breaks. I noticed I had to Rev the engine up to about 75 % for 3 seconds and then release the throttle and the plane with roll about 3 feet and them stop. To taxi I had to gun the throttle up and down and only roll when the throttle was down. I checked there are NO wheel break Physics set up on the model. I think this is do to the weight of the model and the why the engine is over the steering wheels. With the mains so far back and the steering wheels under the props I believe ( I might be wrong ) it is the down thrust being calculated that is adding to much friction to the castering nose wheels.

This helped a the taxing. You will still have to gun the throttle up and down a bit but it will roll better.

Look under Airframe / Floats / steering gear / steering wheel / (Setting call ) Friction Multiplier. Set this to 50 the lowest setting

bear in mind this works with the Airports set up ground friction “ Affects steering and braking friction for this wheel. This is combined with settings in the airport or runways to create the effective braking and steering friction available. “
This does make it roll a bit longer on landing.

If you set the mains to the same 50 setting it will taxi better but now you’ll need to install wheel brakes to get it to stop on paved runways.

I hope this helps.

Boof,

Just a quick question on your inner rib detail. Did you have to shrink the size of your ribs so that the surface rendering didn't get confused in the sim? I've had this problem in the past with several planes I did like the E-Flite Ascent and also the B-1B Lancer when polygons are in very close proximity.

The effect I would get is a fluttering image of underlying surfaces. The ribbing did this bad on the first versions of the Ascent until I fixed it, but the B-1B Lancer looks like it has water vapor forming over the trailing surfaces of the main wings due to the ailerons being so close to the pockets in the wings. It may also be the flaps attemtping to show through.

I'm just curious as to how things turned out for you at least initially since you have so much rib detail.

The effect your talking about is Z fighting where polys at or near the same proximity fight each other to show on top. Thanks to Jeff and others I knew about this problem beforehand and set the skin of the wing larger than the internals. Even so I still had minimal problem with it. I went between max  and RF twice before it was right. It was surprising how far away from each other  the two surfaces had to be, but it is absolutely unnoticeable in RF. I cannot find any evidence of Z fighting anymore.

When I made the Eratix, I duplicated the main component to make the internals. The first thing I did was to set the internal to 99% size. Then I looked over the entire object and moved faces and vertices of the internal structure just to the inside of the external structure, where needed.
I too duplicated the wing. Then I hid the skin and made the internals. Then I un-hid the skin and enlarged. "Six of one half dozen of the other"
You mean, "There's more than one way to skin a cat."
"Same difference"

There were some hints that I got but didn't understand. When I posted the big AirBoss one rater talked about how the prop was way too small. There were a couple of other things I can't recall now. I thought that the model settings might be changing as fliers with different versions of RealFlight downloaded the model.
I noticed!

This is one of the best models I've seen on the swaps in awhile. There are lots of really great things on this. I do see a couple things my perfectionist eye is catching... there is one spot at the wing tip where it meets the fuselage that a color bleeds through onto the fuselage... it is tiny but there. Seems to only be there on the right side. Servos "free-float" in the wing stringers so it looks like they are just black boxes and do not have a brand on the CS... anything will work... even "boof69" brand. PLane had a very stong tendency to tip stall on heavy elevator which indicates tail-heavy... Looked at tail and seemed a little heavy at 3oz. per side so I reduced to 2. V-stab seemed heavy as well... reduced to 2.25. Flew better with no tendency to tip stall. Looked at the motor setup.. thought it strange that the helical and prop wash were severely reduced. Put back to 100%. Also thought it was strange that the "custom engine" had its torque reduced to 50%. Put back and that was a mistake. Something is up there or I missed something discussed here. Weights were adjusted and airfoils seemed reasonable. It still did not "moosh" in the air that I would expect a model of this design to do. I set all stall severity to %65 and that seems right. I would have thought that more would be needed but 65% seems right.

Just my thoughts. Really a wonderful model. I'll enjoy it for some time!

Thanks for the constructive critisizms. I originally had this model flying a bit more docile, but the few that test flew it before release commented on it being underpowered and that it was a pattern flyer in RL so I boosted the power and reset the throws.
As for the tip stall condition its more of a product of a roll coupling issue. If elevator throw is increased its very pronounced.
Tail heavy is not the problem. If anything its always been nose heavy which is why I introduced some incedence in the H-stab and a bit of trim on the elevator. I made the engine mods to get the plane to fly the way the few people that test flew it wanted it to.
I think the color bleed that your seeing is intentional shading I applied. Its all over the model actually its just abit darker there. Its known as ambient occlusion or (AO)
I took off the servo tabs to steal polys for other more visible areas. The idea is that maybe the tabs are below the surface of the covering.(it was a concession).

The AV is the area I am the least skilled and confident. I'm glad through all the concerns that you still like this one.

name: Krill Spark Evo I_EA
description:
This is the Krill models Spark Evo I Designed by Ivo Kryl in response to the collective input of all the F3A pilots and with special input from Andrew Jeskey.


This a great pattern flyer with plenty of power and balance. Knife edge fight is very easy and it knife edge loops in perfect track. The Spark Evo also slows nicely on the downline giving plenty of time for manouvers. Landing is very light and controlable with very low power.

Features a fully modeled RC interior. The canopy and chin hatches come off in a crash or can be released independantly by the "3 pos" switch.





Enjoy

I'll put my scheme's up in a little bit.

One of the interesting things about this airplane design that I noticed was the square attached to the trailing edge of the rudder.

This is done in boats too. It is a poormans version of a Becker Rudder system used in full sized ships and tugboats. A Becker rudder has an articulated flap at the trailing edge that turns sharper when the main rudder turns.

The poor mans version is a piece of square tubing attached to the trailing edge. It has sort of a permanent articulated flap. When going straight ahead, there is no effect. When the rudder is turned however, the edge of the square is at a sharper angle, giving the same effect as a Becker rudder, to a degree anyway.

So on this airplane, the designer did the same thing it appears, making for a much more powerful rudder reaction.
Yes the rudder has a unique feature but I was unable to replicate it in the sim.

name: SpaceWalker50%_EA
description:
SpaceWalker Single seat 50%
The SpaceWalker is a nice low wing gentle flyer. First flew in 1986 and designed by Jessi Anglin as a throw back to the golden age of aviation.
This particular SpaceWalker takes all design ques from Mr. Jim Dietrick's build of a semi-scale single seat 50% SpaceWalker.
From the dummy 4 cylinder engine and PVC exhaust to the cockpit pad and istrument panel. This model has a 13ft wing span and 71/2ft nose to tail.

This plane is as close to the actual models flight physics as possible. At 54lbs this plane still flys quite nimbly. Yet will squat on those hard landings as you would expect a heavy model to do.


Thanks to Abaser the landing gear are fully articulated. Meaning both the shocks and gear flex and move with contact with the ground.
Also the cockpit has a working ball level and a semi working compass on the dash. I couldn't get it to hold a particular direction.





Enjoy

The all silver with treaded tires IS RC landing gear for 1/2 scale SW. If you wish I can photo the Robart gear I use on my SW's. The Robart site will provide you with Great drawings that you can use to scale the LG to what ever scale. Look up CUB Gear.
The FS SW'ers use fiberglass wing tips, avalible to those that want them, however there have been a few SW'ers that the builders decided to do something similar to the wing tips on a Super Sporster.
The Fiberglass tips are attatched with screws and then the seam is covered with rib stitch tapes and blended in with primer and paint on FS.
As for Fillets, FS SW's had none and the only one I know of that has was a custom mod by the builder of the Round Engine SW flying down under.
All RC SW's have fiberglass or plastic wing tips. All come with factory provided wire landing gear, well the scale looking ones, the 1/2 scale uses the gear in the photo.
I am recreating the Jim Dietrich SW. So I want to use what he did for gear and copy the cockpit detail.

@Flex, Could you find some pics of the covering techniques you are describing. I have covered using mono and econo Kote only. I know nothing about fabric covering. For instance where would the seams be placed and where is the pinking tape be used. If you want it to be an accurate visual representation I will need some examples.

cloth covering

Here is one link, with a lot more links. This will help bring you up to speed on the process for full scale. On models we would use clear Dope, and would only run the pinking tape on top of ribs, and on tail feathers. On models it is done just for show. It is called pinking tape because the edges are cut with pinking seizers.
I will ask Jim to take some picks of the two seater covering, and send you.

I lost that link.
Sig coverall is very popular.
I just need to see the end effect. What is the width of the tape and what is it simulating. I really need to see the way you guys went about everything.

The final appearance is opaque correct? or can you see through it a bit? If it's the later it won't matter because the wing has no internals. Why does the tape need to be pinked, and why is it needed on every rib?

On full scale the tape is pinked to keep it from unraveling, and leaving strings everywhere. This is a pick of tape made for models that gives the apearance of the stiching with the tape. In the old days, they did not have the glues we have today, so they stiched the tape to the rib so it would not blow off. Tap is used on full scale covering to reinforce the cloth where it rubs on the ribs, so it won't fale.

One that questioned why it was upside down. Then he explained what it was
They are used in turn coordinators.

This a ball gauge.

A bubble gauge the tube bends down at both ends. The bubble stays in the middle.

With a ball gauge the ball rolls to the low end on a aileron roll. When you turn with the rudder and ailerons ( in a flat turn ) the ball will get thrown out to the opposite end so you try to keep it in the middle to keep your wings level. Not sure if that will work in RF.
Actually It's quite accurate. I believe a turn coordinator would work fine in RF. I used an AFS Gyro with the gain maxed out to pivot the ball in the tube.

I have the same thing on the front of my RV.  There's a giant ball bearing in it.   (The shape on top of the ball bearing in the tube is a small level facing front to back, but it's a bubble.)  Same thing in my bucket truck at work, too.  You wouldn't want to go up in a bucket if the vehicle is leaning too much!

I think that the setup of this plane is really top notch. The flight characteristics are really spot on and the CS is beautiful and bump map are quite crisp and it really grabs the eye.

My only criticism is the lack of flaws in the CS/bump map... let me explain. When you cover a bird this size generally you will have areas that will be glassed, fabric, etc. There really is no differentiation between materials. This difference also lends to human error or otherwise. Example: Fabric or film covering is NEVER perfect. Addition of stretching on the seams at compound curve points and inconsistency in adhesion on ribs all add to the character of a model. The Escapade is a great subject to study on this. The other thing missing is dirt. Wheel pants have no grass stains or runway dirt. The motor never seems to place a drop of slime on the plane. Dirty it up a bit and give it some love. While it is generally a practice of gas or glow pilots to wipe after a flying session there usually remains some evidence that exhaust has been present.

Please keep in mind that I am very impressed with this subject. These little details are an additional layer of difficulty usually only attended to by modelers who work for KE. Upping the ante here and just trying to push you a little more. I've never been able to accomplish all this as I usually run out of steam on a model to get all this. Even a smudged fingerprint around a screw point would add that extra touch.

I think that the setup of this plane is really top notch. The flight characteristics are really spot on and the CS is beautiful and bump map are quite crisp and it really grabs the eye.

My only criticism is the lack of flaws in the CS/bump map... let me explain. When you cover a bird this size generally you will have areas that will be glassed, fabric, etc. There really is no differentiation between materials. This difference also lends to human error or otherwise. Example: Fabric or film covering is NEVER perfect. Addition of stretching on the seams at compound curve points and inconsistency in adhesion on ribs all add to the character of a model. The Escapade is a great subject to study on this. The other thing missing is dirt. Wheel pants have no grass stains or runway dirt. The motor never seems to place a drop of slime on the plane. Dirty it up a bit and give it some love. While it is generally a practice of gas or glow pilots to wipe after a flying session there usually remains some evidence that exhaust has been present.

Please keep in mind that I am very impressed with this subject. These little details are an additional layer of difficulty usually only attended to by modelers who work for KE. Upping the ante here and just trying to push you a little more. I've never been able to accomplish all this as I usually run out of steam on a model to get all this. Even a smudged fingerprint around a screw point would add that extra touch.

name: Bristol M1_EA
description:
This is the Bristol M1c. The third revision of the Bristol M1 designed in 1916 by Frank Barnwell and built by the Bristol Aeroplan Corporation. Despite the higher speed and better manuverability It was rejected for it's high landing speeds that prevented it from landing in the small French airfields and the belief at the time that monoplanes were inherently unstable. Despite the percieved drawbacks the British Air Ministry ordered 125 of the Bristiol M1c. Changes from the M1A and M1B were the LeRone 9 cylinder rotary engine and a centrally mounted Vickers .303 machine gun.



Features:
Fixed scope camera------------------------------------F4
Fixed wing port cameras-------------------------------F6 and F7
Vickers machine gun------------------------------------Dual rates swithch
Detachable cowl to view the 9 cylinder LeRone----3 pos switch down position

Thanks to those who test flew and gave input.





Enjoy

Fantastic build thread here:
http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=724898

PR makes a great kit for this one. See post # 41 for a cockpit pic... chose your polys wisely. Lots of fun panel lines and sub-ribs... rib stitching... guy wires... Rotating LaRhone motor... You have your work cut out on this one. I'll be watching.
You had doubts about the spacewalker early in its build. Any thoughts?

Oh boy!

Woo-woo, on the job.

General characteristics

Crew: one, pilot
Length: 20 ft 5 in (6.24 m)
Wingspan: 30 ft 9 in (9.37 m)
Height: 7 ft 9 in (2.37 m)
Wing area: 145 ft² [1] (13.6 m²)
Empty weight: 900 lb [1] (409 kg)
Loaded weight: 1,348 lb (611 kg)
Powerplant: 1 × Le Rhône 9J rotary engine, 110 hp (82 kW)

Performance

Maximum speed: 113 knots (130 mph, 209 km/h) at sea level
Service ceiling: 20,000 ft (6,096 m)
Endurance: 1 hr 45 mins

Armament

Guns: 1 × fixed-forward .303 in (7.7 mm) Vickers machine gun

Wing windows

http://richard.ferriere.free.fr/3vues/bristolm1_3v.jpg
This one shows them better.

UUUUsefulll!
Tonight's progress.
Did some more just before bed. The wing brace tower was fun to get joined up at the point. I'm a bit lost as to how the main gear suspension works, so I'm not sure how to model it yet. Any idea?

When I got to the steering gear of the SportCruiser, I was stumped as to how it could turn.  I did a lot of research, and found out that it only turns by swiveling as you apply either the left or the right brake.  I was surprised to find that out.  It is interesting, the things you learn about aircraft while modeling, no?
Most definetily. I didn't know allot about aircraft just one year ago. I learn more every build.

I'm leaning towards a cream base color with the bulls-eye accents for the color scheme.

Find as much reference as you can that will show the authentic color schemes for the M1.

Also know this I will not make this an over sized model. You can do that post.
We can discuss the final scale of this model once that information is in hand.
Click to expand...
I can only find one pic of the creme colored plane. I think that is a pic of a small model. There are lot of pics of replica full size planes. If you are going "scale" on this plane, you might need to pick a color scheme where we can find accurate documentation.

I had the Balsa USA model. I believe that the wingspan was 60". I do not have a preference for size beyond that. However, if you are going to model in a lot of detail, the results of your work will display better on big birds. FWIW, I am not really as for gone on on giant scale as it might seem. However, fast is important to me.
Well this model wasn't fast. Unless you consider 130mph fast.
130mph seems very fast to me for a model. My one and only 60-sized model probably only flies 70-80 mph.
Sorry I meant the full size model did 130. The RC should do a scale version of that speed.

Fast

I initially powered the Bristol that I built with an OS48 4-stroke. It felt like scale WW1 speed with that motor. I could never get that motor to run like I expected (inverted, airflow through the cowling, fuel feed). I changed the motor to an OS32 2 stroke and flew the plane like that for at least a year. When I moved the 32 to a psudeo F-20, I hung the Bristol airframe up in my garage. Some time later, I sold the airframe to another club member (Jackson Flyers, Fort Jackson, Columbia, SC). This guy put a K&B 60 in the plane and it flew very well until the wings came off.

Andy

What would be a good size then? 10ft ws? That would be 33%. Smaller than that?

size matters

If you are asking me about size, I do not have a preference. However, I did get excited when you said 15'.

Trying to put it into perspective, most of the 33% model airplanes are models of full scale planes that are typically small in real life. The aerobatic jobs.

A 50% scale plane is rare. Of any full size plane. Although it has been done, but it borders on the ridiculous.

Regardless of the 'percentage', a 10' wingspan model is huge, and realistically about as large as you will ever see at a model airfield except maybe the Joe Nall fly-in where Carl Hubacher brings his 4-engine jobs. And yes, I know about La Ferte' in France, but again those models are highly out of the ordinary and not what you see at a typical model airfield.

So then you need to ask yourself, is this Bristol going to be something a typical scale modeler would have? Or something out of the ordinary that gets brought out once a year to a special fly-in?

The Balsa USA model of the Bristol has a 60" wingspan.

http://shop.balsausa.com/product_p/436.htm

I have always felt that RF doesn't represent scale very well. Models always seem on the small side. The Bristol M1 is a small plane in RL. 30ft wing span 2 ft larger than the SpaceWalker. I represented the SW as a 50% or 13ft but it doesn't seem that large in RF to me anyways. I'm not fighting for the 15ft 50% idea but 5ft in RF is too small. I have plans for much detail on this one and much will go unnoticed at such a small scale. I think it will fall somewhere between the two. Maybe 8ft. I don't know,I'll export in multiple sizes and take screens in RF and see what happens.

Models always seem on the small side.
I agree with you whole hartedly. Not only do the models look small on the ground, but look much smaller a K out. You're model, you're call. If it just looks like a blur, pretty hard to get the effect!

So I took a picture of a 5ft,8ft,10ft,15ft version of the Bristol. I also did a comparison shot with them all lined up. I'll reserve my opinions until others have weighed in. Let me know what you think.
It'd look better in green.
I thought i'd let keep your own style and go blue. GO BLUE!

If you open it up for discussion, each respondent will have their own opinion on what size is appropriate.
Two ways to go about this:
* Being that it's an R/C sim, which specific real-life model are you trying to simulate?
* If you're just going for showcasing a pretty model, then go for the best size that will accomplish that.

Your bird your choice.

This is a photo captured from a video of my maiden flight of my Four Star 60. The RF screen shot is as close as I could get it, going back and forth from the sim to my desktop. A photofield sim also comes out slightly different in perspective than real life.

But anyway, the two planes are very close in size. The sim version does seem slightly larger though to me.
Click to expand...
The planes are exactly 1 1/8 inches long on both shots, the RF has more vibrant colors, otherwise the planes are basically the same size. This makes the RF model "EASIER" to see and appear more detailed, colors ect than the other.

It is interesting to analyze, but I'm not sure the zoom level is the same in each picture.  The angle of the runway is different in each shot.  The background objects are offset in each picture, too.  As close as these 2 shots are to each other, I'd still say the results are inconclusive.

Maybe this is why I feel scale is off in RF. I am using Joe's Garage AP for this comparison so I could position the camera without perspective. Relative scale from environment to model is not proportionate to real world scale.
So since the discussion involves the Bristol's scale I will use it to demonstrate. The first picture shows the visual scale of the Bristol: 10.09ft. If I set it on almost any runway in the sim this problem can be seen. Lane widths in the U.S vary from 9ft to 12 ft 12ft being the standard for highways and narrower widths for surface streets. In the second picture I have positioned the bristol on the left lane. If scale in RF were correct the lane should be no more than 2ft wider than the bristol. More likely though the road should be the same width or narrower. The last picture shows that the road's total width at Joe's is 41.20ft. Those are some luxurious lanes at 20ft a piece. To have a model in real flight that actually looks like a 10ft wing span you would need to make it 20ft.
So I stand by my contention that planes seem small in RF. So I don't think a 10ft wing span for the Bristol M1 is too much for RF.

Seems like the AP designers should have done as much homework as you to make the runways correct. However, it appears to me the scale is about right in comparison. A 10ft span plane would be around half the width of a 20 ft lane

Boof, the Bristol is brilliant! Quite a masterpiece, actually.

As far as the 'goodies' go, I noticed a couple things. When looking through the scope, or in cockpit mode, I cannot see any tracers and there are no bullet strikes on the ground. However, in chase mode I can see them. Is that just my computer, or is it something that is missing?

Its a limitation in the sim. The prop when spinning is a transprency and the windshield or scope lens are transparencies. You can only see use one transparency at a time in RF. Notice when in the cockpit cam that the prop isn't visible through the windshield either. Since tracers and partices lke the groundstrike of the bullets are also using transparency you are unable to see those either even if you reduced the prop size to 1% so that it is no longer visible the windshield would erase the particles and tracers from view. Appreciate the kind review.

From the RF Editor:

Enter a comma-separated list of vehicle frames to render in the foreground when this camera is active. Due to the limitations of computer hardware, some transparent features, such as aircraft smoke, are not normally visible when the camera must look through another transparent feature, such as a canopy. This problem is solved by adding the canopy frame to the list of "Foreground Frames".

In the editor, select: "2CockPitCamera" With advanced settings displayed, enter ~CS_WS in the Foreground Frames area, and you will now see the muzzle flash and the groundstrikes from the pilot's view. Tracer's are visible as well, but you will need to be turning away, or diving away, from your previous shots, since the gun and flash hide the tracers that are right in front of you.

I can't quite get the scope to show any of it, but the answer may lie in the foreground frames and/or Excluded Frames, and or Near Plane Distance.

...and on camera 1ScopeCamera, type ~CS_SPYG into foreground frames and you will now see the same through the scope camera. Sweet!
