In addition to boof's comments. Proper renderings in 3ds Max can really make a model look it's best (the old Ricky Delton) was best at his renderings in Max.....his finished models looked identical to pictures of the real model. If a modeler has spent untold hours creating a project and wants to see it at it's "best" (which certainly isn't in the RF environment) than he has every right to do so.

Like I mentioned above the photo realistic renderings that Ricky was capable of were awesome, but the "soft" renders (like the Goon model above) that boof, myself and others do give the model a very unique almost "clay" like look....it's nice to take a step back and look at that on your computer screen at times as well.

I went back to find a couple of Rick's (Flyguys') excellent renders....it appears he deleted most if not all of them. However here is a picture that someone else posted showing how they turned his rendering into their "desktop" on their computer. This is why it's fun to render (not that I can render anything close to this....wish I could!!) RF has good graphics, but could never make a model look this photo real.

Part of what I'm trying to say is that I won't feel like somebody hates me or doesn't appreciate me just because they critcize me.  I think that would go a long way for many members here.  If somebody mentions a flaw in a model I'm building, and I get what they are talking about, I'll fix the problem, maybe.  That doesn't mean that I'll fix anything someone mentions.  Sometimes I may feel he is in error, or that it's too minor to change.  Anybody can say anything they want to about my models.  Most of it would go in one ear and out the other.  But, depending on who you are, I may take what you say to heart, and try to improve the model or my process.  Person A could tell me my model sucks, and I couldn't care less about his opinion.  Person B could tell me my model sucks, and he'll have my attention.  Even if he told me it was an awful model, I wouldn't think less of him or assume he hates me.  I would listen to him, and take his advice to heart.  Not because I'm trying to impress him or anyone else, but because I know he knows what he's talking about.  Many of you, including you, Boof, have helped me to become a better modeler.  For that I am grateful.

To be honest I did and do it for visual impact, and I personally don't use quality renders for error checking. Let's just file it under a nice touch. I like it when the other modelers do good renders along with screenies. I do renders like this on all my projects and thought it would be nice to share. I'm sorry for taking offense Maj. I didn't get that you thought it might be possible for a render to help the model in RF.


As far as saying something nice for the sake of saying something nice, I think I'll pass.

name: GreatPlanes Phazer_EA
description:
Great Planes Phazer
This is a bungee and hand launch 90+ mph EDF Delta wing jet. Powered by an Ammo GPMG5185 brushless in-runner housed in a HyperFlow EDF unit, 35A ESC, and a 4s2200mAh lipo. This is a 3 channel model and is rudderless.

The Phazer for RealFlight runs as close to the real thing as possible. It is very fast and crisp on the controls.

Special Thanks to Madratter for his suggestions with concern to the prop to get the speed and flight times within normal range.

Features:
Animated pushrods





Enjoy

threadData.body: This one comes from the request thread. Hilcat72 requested this quite some time ago. I started on this tonight after dinner and it flowed nicely. I just need to model the flat painted pilot, the EDF, and electronics that show. Nothing has been optimized and I'm at 7,758.
Anyways......
Feeling a little lonely? Actually, I think it is great you are picking this up for Hilcat.
Thank You

name: A-10 Thunderbolt II Warthog_EA
description:
The Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II (Warthog) is an American single-seat, twin-engine, straight-wing jet aircraft developed by Fairchild-Republic in the early 1970s. The A-10 was designed for a United States Air Force (USAF) requirement to provide close air support (CAS) for ground forces by attacking tanks and other armored vehicles, and other ground targets with a limited air defense capability. It was the first USAF aircraft designed solely for CAS.


Special Thanks to csgill75 for his TF34-GE-400A sound profile for the engines.

Gun spin controlled by middle position of the 3 pos switch (Channel 8)
Gun firing is controlled by the far position of the 3 pos switch (Channel 5)
Split ailerons (Deceleron) are controlled by the rates switch (Channel 5)
Retracts are controlled by the retract/Smoke switch (Channel 7)
All of the load out is represented in the physics model using detachable pods.
None of which are setup to be released but most of the work is done for any one that wishes to make them dropable.





Enjoy

Did a little more research on those Slats on the LE, they are not designed for slow speed flight like I mentioned, they are actually designed for high AoA maneauvers, they only extend 6 inches on the full scale aircraft, and are only on the top half of the wing, to allow air to pass underneath, acting as a duct to direct air into the nacelles when the wing is blocking the airflow.

I was just setting up the scissor pivots for the 4 flaps on the wart and thought I'd do an animation in Max and show the helpers in action. The placement of the helpers isn't hyper critical. In this situation I set the anchor pivot at the same Z as the flap it controls and then moved it forward an arbitrary amount. I then shift+move copied a helper from the anchor helper to become the hinge of the scissor pivot. I scaled it down a bit for a visual cue. The anchor helper is parented to the wing the hinge helper is parented to the anchor and the flap to the hinge helper. When the anchor helper is rotated 15° the hinge and flap follow. Then the hinge rotates -10° to bring the flap back up into alignment with the wing. then the flap is rotated 20°. When these rotation happen simultaneously in RF the result is just what you see in the animation.

Check it out.

Well the answer was in dhk79's setup.
What I had to do though was to make 4 servos, one per deceleron half. Each of those servos requires a dedicated output channel. (1/3 of the available output channels).
Each of those output channels requires 2 (complex) input feeds.
Input 1 of each controls aileron movement and the complex feed is necessary to reduce the movement from the full throw required by the airbrakes.
Input 2 of each controls airbrake movement and the complex feed is necessary to control the direction of throw.
Since the lower deceleron doesn't respond to aileron movement when in the airbrake configuration their input 2 "Logic" is set to "Override all other feeds". Also this feed needed to be set to only activate when the dual rates switch is up.

It works well in flight. Airbrakes work noticeably and roll control is still responsive.

Nice, hope it works out OK. For now I just mixed some sounds, so only at max RPM the fan sound is heard.
The preview I posted above shows the current results. The sounds work well on my sound setup.

One thing that prevented me from adding that sound to the original is the way the Doppler effect is handled in RF. when the plane is coming at you it sounds great with the fan sound however after it fly's by it sounds more like a NASCAR car going by which kinda ruins it for me at least. If we could edit the sound files in such a way that the coming and going sounds are 2 different sets of sound files, then after it passes by the fan noise could be drowned out by the jet blast sound.  That's why i chose to have it in the sound set but at a lower volume so we don't get the race car sound as it leaves the area.

I have created a short video with the fan sound on the A-10 to show what i am talking about when it comes to the Doppler effect, notice that when the plane is flying away at full throttle it kinda sounds like a race car engine When flying towards you however, it sounds like it's supposed to though.

name: RangeVideoJet_EA
description:
Range Video Jet is an FPV platform from Range Video
The real world model can be built in many configurations
By adding middle wing sections the wingspan can be changed.
Even 2 fuselage configs are possible.
This simulator model is the long configuration and has an
FPV camera view


Camera Gimbal Horizontal is controlled by right slider
Camera Gimbal Vertical is controlled by left slider


Enjoy

threadData.body:
This was started a long time ago and I just decided to open it up and do more work on it.
This is known as the RV Jet and it seems pretty sweet by all accounts. This model comes with each wing in two sections. This allows for a short winged fast flyer and a longer winged slow(er) flyer. The configurations do not stop there. More mid sections can be added and really extend the width of this model. Even multiple fuselage variations are possible.
This plane is a pusher to allow for an unobstructed view from the dome covered fully gimballed camera mount.
I plan on releasing different configurations as in the real world.
I also have some ideas on control setups allowing for better control of the camera gimbal.
This is a brilliant video reviewing the RVJet
Polys are at 17,393

Here are some configurations that are possible in the real world. Obviously the poly limit will not allow for them all but they are still interesting.

It looks so detailed and real!
Thanks Andy and jjf. I still have a lot of polys to work with. Hope I can show even more detail.

Looks really awesome, true to life!

FK14 Le Mans_EA

This is the FK14 Le Mans. Designed and manufactured by FK-Light Planes from Poland. It is a very unique personal cruiser. A one piece hood opens for full access to the cabin. Side by side seating and controls contained in a sports car like...
www.knifeedge.com

I noticed the reference to the FK 14 Le Mans in post #49 so I thought I would download the model and give it a try, WOW ! that is an excellent model that fly's great in RF9 and RF-X, I like the instrument panel all lit up for night flights and the cockpit detail is incredible, right down to the leather seats with superb stitch work.
Thanks asj5547. I really enjoyed making that one.

I'm pretty sick of working on these models and not uploading anything. So I think I will be deleting the electronics and sealing the lid on this thing. I have the physics pretty much done and the CS doesn't really need a lot of work. Frankly wires are a nightmare to do and I just don't wanna

Okay I have it working in RF-X. What I did was replace the 4 piece wing with a single piece wing. I also modified the CG some but I don't think that had anything to do with the breaking apart problem. RF-X always seems to have some quirks so I just took a chance a four piece wing might be the problem and tried it. Anyway ASJ here's a Test RFX for you to try out and see if it works there too.

Also the camera doesn't work but I haven't worked on that. It doesn't move or put out video when you select it with the function keys.
I figured a single wing would work better but it's not as accurate for the physics model. Not sure why the camera wouldn't be working. This version works in RF-9

I tried the RangeVideoJetTST again tonight but after I flew it for a while the plane broke apart again and after that I couldn't launch it anymore until I went back to the main menu and hit the "Fly" button again, then it would launch again. After the plane broke apart when you tried to launch it the plane would instantly go back to the launch position almost like you didn't launch it. So the fix isn't really a fix. So I think that's it for me.

Oh I did find out why the camera wasn't moving it seems it's because RF-X was before the latest Interlink DX and doesn't have the channels used to move and zoom the camera. Also I'm using the Interlink X so I changed the channels to the standard ch 9 and ch 10 and used the ch 6 knob for the zoom and the camera was moving and zooming in the editor but I still had a gray area for the video on the field so there was something else wrong. But at least the camera is moving and zooming now. Anyway I'm going back to work on the Sportster so ASJ this information is mostly for you.

I have been working on the Range Video Jet RF-X version and have not found a suitable fix.
Technoid's one wing panel (physics) solution works great but once the model crashes or breaks apart in mid flight it reverts back to acting like a non collision mesh model, but this model has collision mesh.
Another short term fix is to name all wing panels RMW LMW but again only till the model crashes or resets.
I deleted a wing panel/section in the physics editor (a lot of planes with 3 sections work perfect i RF-X) but again not for the RVJ. I also changed the leading edge sweeps for inner and mid wing panels in the editor to see if the positive/negative angles were causing an issue, again no fix.
I tried every combination of strength setting possible for wing and fuselage, even with everything set to max (1500) the model will still just blow apart when passing objects, like a tree or launched too close to the ground.

To get the RVJ to fly well I had to make changes to the Center of Pressure Variability(%) and Aspect Ratio Factor Scale(%) of the main fuselage. I also changed the Center of Pressure Variability(%), Center of Pressure Modification -Top(%), and Aspect Ratio Factor Scale(%) for the NoseCap and CameraDome fuselage objects. After 2 days of trying to make the Range Video Jet fly and not break apart in RF-X I finally found the fix, add weight to the wings, RF-X must be calculating the weight to size of the wings as too "delicate" and allows the wings to flex aggressively (flaps like a Humming Bird) and then the model breaks apart.
So I doubled the 4 wing section weights and the model would fly good at most airports, but to fly from the Sierra Nevada Cliff airport and launch over the railing, quad weight was needed, also increased the nose cone weight to keep CG correct.
Thanks for this great model Boof69, awesome model, I love it.

I've seen a number of people say their 1060 wasn't enough they got slow frame rates, then others said they were okay. It depends on how sensitive you are to lower frame rates. Being honest I don't think you'll enjoy RF-X that well with your system but since you can get it at a pretty low cost at least you'd be able to try it and see the better looking graphics it has.

What resolution is your monitor? Maybe better put what resolution do you run RealFlight at? I say that because some don't run a game (sim) at the native resolution of their monitor. RealFlight 9 is VERY easy on the graphics card so you can't compare it with RF-X.

Click to expand...
You know there was so much variance in what people said back then it wasn't funny, but more times than not your system would be on the low end. But going by the RF-X System Requirements it was an Optimal System. But almost everyone thought the system requirements was a joke.

I had an I7 4770S at 3.1 GHZ with 32 GB of RAM and a GTX760 when I got RF-X and I didn't like the frame rates I was getting at 1920x1200 to me they were painful frame rates for an aircraft simulator, others could tolerate it.

Your graphics card would give you a "clear" advantage over my system when I first got RF-X because of the GTX1060 but your CPU on the other hand is way slower than what I had at the time yours 2.2 Ghz mine 3.1 Ghz and it does take some CPU horsepower to push the frame rates in RF-X it just takes a lot more GPU than CPU. But the CPU has to push the simulator at a decent frame rate before a GPU matters at all. I don't know how much you know about how the CPU and GPU affect frame rates but there's quite a bit to it. But first it's important that the CPU can process the frames fast enough before the GPU can do anything with them. So there's an important balance. But RF-X is way harder on the GPU than the CPU.

Here's two charts I created at the time that might help you. All the information you want to know is in the chart just read it and you should get a decent picture of what my system did at the time. Now the updates they did helped so if you get it be sure to update it fully before trying it out because that really helps. And try out the Wright Island field right away it's by far the best field they did. But some of the others let you fly in the mountains and are definitely cool.

But honestly if your CPU can push a decent frame rate (don't know) I think for 40 bucks I'd get it just to see what RF-X is all about. But be sure to patch it to the latest release before you try it out because that makes A LOT of difference in frame rates.

An alternative CS is always going to be an option on any mapped part. You can't bake graphics. However, the CS will always be available and if another is created, it's your choice to DL it or not.

There are areas like the one I circled in gold where there is clearly a vertex, but the triangulation does not go to that vertex. But I think I figured it out. All those areas I can find are just 4-gons. It is possible at times for 3ds max to not obviously triangulate even larger n-gons (like when creating cylinders).

I traced the frame and the openings using splines and combined them all then converted to a poly. Then I hand connected all the verts to only be 3 or 4 sides. Then I applied a shell modifier to give thickness and to keep the same triangulation on the other side.

The place you circled is just a 4th vert making a 4 sided poly. You could cut in another edge but it would only visually confuse things. If you go to Polygon selection mode then go down to "edit triangulation" you will see how max has divided the quad to make 2 tris.

I have had my grand daughter all day but have had chances to get some work done it's not allot but there are advancements. I've added frame screw heads and collars, More holes in the frame CF, especially the slits at the top rear of the frame, and rubber strands for the battery holds. I'm not stumped but the upper transmission bearing block and servo mount is a complicated part and keeping it's poly count down is tough. I have the upper portion of it fairly dialed in but I still need to shape the lower portion and add the outer servo mounts. If that's not enough for this single part it is also the mount location for the anti-rotation CF tower.

What's left to do is the Main and rear rotors, Drive belts, Electronics components and wires, Four Servos(3 direct drive around the main shaft and the one in the tail), Pads for the skids, and collision mesh. Then if polys allow I will put in more details so less will need to be put on the CS. I will obviously need to to the gear teeth in the CS and Bump.

All of the current CS elements are still temporary. I am mapping as I go along so adding in the impresion of the final colors helps the artistic process.

Polys are at 8,996

All in all I'm very pleased with the progress and the appearance of this model so far.

I know that if Steve was still here he would be very excited for this build and would have had allot to say and suggest for the model. I remain dedicated to doing this one to the best of my ability. Helis are fun to build!
Still looking very very good. I have said it before but I'll say it again. The speed you can build just amazes me.

Nice job! Yes, Steve would be bouncing off the walls on this build. Hell, he was bouncing already before I ever said for sure that I would do it. I'm glad I handed it to you instead. Much nicer and further along than I would ever be.

Thanks guys. I'm feeling very driven on this one. I could have been further along but the family has been demanding more of my time lately. Today will be tough to get allot of time on the Goblin. Monday will be a big day for it though. I will post lots pics along the way.

One Month ago I asked Boof, if there is a chance to get a Copy of the Goblin without the "td9cowboy" Logo. At this time I didn´t know whats the story behind the Logo.

So this month is nearly over and I wroted a PM to Boof today, asking for this Logo free Version. Then he told me, that he will not remove that logo from it. I said that not the Logo is the problem, is more the position, cause many pilots love to place their Pilotsname exactly at this position. I think the main point you didn't understand was that once you upload an EA and some one else makes a CS or an AV for it you can no longer remove the file to make room for a re- upload with changes. It is not a common practice for the modelers I know of to release multiple EAs for the same model. I always cringe when something is wrong with my models that I let slip and make it to the swaps. I strive to do the best of my ability at the time of release. I continue to learn new things so hopefully my models get progressively better. I don't think that I have seen any model, including the ones created by KE, satisfy everyone. There are just too many limits in this sandbox to allow the precision I'd like to be capable of. So at some point I cut the cord and let the model go and move to the next project as most of us here do. You will see later if you stick with this particular hobby that it's not easy to create a model that all will be happy with, so you will learn to release it when you are happy with it. All in all I am quite happy with the Goblin 700. Happier in fact than I am with several of my earlier projects. No regrets!

Can anyone edit your tables that you create, or make a different color scheme? The problem with updating an EA is that if someone has created a CS or AV for your model, RF will only use THAT model. If you update an existing model and try to download a CS or AV for the original, it will not work, as the updated EA would be a different model.

Yes. I've been modeling about 9 months or so now, and I still continue to learn things on a frequent basis. In fact, if I didn't continue to learn things, I would probably grow bored of it and quit.

Little hint about canopies: Start with a tiny sphere at the very nose of the canopy and rotate it so the vertex at it's pole is the very tip. Now grab the back 2/3rds of verts and stretch them back a bit using the move tool. Scale them all up so that the forward most edgeloop meets the limits of the canopy and deselect that edgeloop and continue that process till you reach the rear of the canopy. Add in edgeloops wherever necessary to get a good shape. Now shape from the perpendicular view to the one you started with. Now all you need to do is use the cut tool to draw in the rear cut of the canopy and delete the unnecessary polys.

name: Outrage Velocity 90N2 FBL_EA
description:
Outrage Velocity 90 N2 FBL

This is the second vision of the Velocity 90 N not yet released for sale. This model was made with the cooperation of Outrage and includes all of the changes between this model and it's predecessor. If you are familiar with the Velocity 90 N you will notice most of the changes aft of the main shaft. New CNC aluminium forward and rear tail rotor gear boxes. The main gear has been upgraded and the horizontal fin is omitted. Among other changes.


Features many animated push rods and a fully modeled YS-91 engine.
Canopy release.......................Channel 6 (Knob)





Enjoy

threadData.body:
This is the Outrage Velocity 90. The same company that makes the Torq servos I used on the Goblin have a line of helis. This is their big nitro bird.
I contacted the company to get good pics and a 3-view and they sent me a special photoshoot but they ran out of steam for the 3-view. I went back to the website and their background image is a side and top view of the heli but the right click gives no option for saving the image so the pics below show how I obtained the image. The image is really big at 3840x2400.
I was able to process the pics and make them more usable. I setup the image planes this morning and will start this build today.
You'll notice the side view copied and laying flat on the grid. That's to make it easier to trace the frame with the line tool.
He said trace!

One reason the helicopters don't interest me as much in terms of modeling, is that once the canopy is on, a lot of them look very similar. But in this particular case, because it is a nitro bird, it will be very different from the Goblin build.

Those 3 views (actually 2-views) look like they should be pretty good/excellent.

I always felt the same way, but always knew I was going to try one just to be more rounded in this hobby. Now that I have modeled one I know they are fun to model. It is different than making planks. It almost feels like you are assembling a real heli. By the way the canopy pops off in lite collisions. Then all the detail shows.
How could you resist w/actual blueprints. I've been thinking of trying a heli also just to see if I could make one.
I think you'd like it. There are some things about the pivots and naming convention for the rotors that take a minute to wrap your head around, but once past that it's not that hard.

So I modeled The YS 91 sr that is recommended for this heli. The carb still needs work but It's getting there. I imported the Outrage Torq servos I used on the Goblin and have placed them around the machine. They still carry the AO map used on the goblin so their color isn't right. Also the servo mounting tabs are on the inside of the frames with this one so I still need to make hardware for those. The detail for the frames has been increased with all the various visible holes. Muffler is in place as well. Polys are at 9370.
Still left to model are both main and tail rotors, canopy, tail bracing, electronics, and fuel plumbing. Of coarse the collision mess as well. I can steal allot of polys from the frame if need be.

What are the feathering arms still on the helicopter for?
Click to expand...
Feathering Arms?

I have Flybarred and flybarless heli's and the only things with feathers in the name is the feathering shaft

In the picture you posted there are a couple arms that attach to the Swash plate, those are Mixers that just keep the swash plate spinning inline with the head so links from the swash to the grips are lined up. The swash would not spin in sync with the head and the ball links would not work properly to control the grips if it wasn't for those arms. On my DFC head on my T-rex, it doesn't have those Mixer arms since the links from the Swash to the head are solid aluminum and not just ball links. A cleaner setup in my opinion. the goblin has a similar setup and doesn't have the mixer arms.

Well I don't know helis hence my confusion about what things are called. That's why I put the question out there to you heli guys. If I knew they were mixer arms then I wouldn't have needed to ask the question.

I have spent some time testing the problem of the blur disk for this heli and I have discovered some things that the tutorials do not cover nor could I find discussion about the subject. Firstly you can only have a single material applied. You can map it and use an external texture and you can even use opacity but it is still only a singe material. You can put a baked material on the blur disk but you cannot use 2 baked materials. The head on the Velocity is black and aluminium and I was using baked materials to show both in the blur disk.
The other issue is using specular in the material. This will lessen the effect of a spinning head.
The shots below are not a fair representation of how things look in the sim but it is no longer a problem.

Just want to say that your Outrage Velocity 90 N2 has surpassed the Synergy N5c FBL as my favorite heli to fly in RF! Outstanding job! I want more!!!

It's also worth noting that immediately after downloading the V90N2 I, for whatever reason, decided to make yet another attempt at learning piro flips. I'm not sure if it was the heli or just a strange coincidence, but (after an hour and a half) I finally got it! I can now do piro flips, although a good deal of refinement is needed.

(A little background: I've been flying on and off for the past ~10 years. I taught myself how to fly helis on RF G2, before flying my first heli, a Thunder Tiger Raptor .30 V2. I have always wanted to be able to do piro flips, because I think they're one of the coolest looking maneuvers but, for whatever reason, could never figure them out until now. FINALLY!!! )

Thanks so much. I have heard from some good heli pilots that my model has a light feel. That it sinks slowly even in autos. This is probably what has made it a bit easier to learn piros. I glad you were able to get the maneuver down. Maybe I'll learn how some day.

name: Mikado Logo 800 Xxtreme_EA
description:
MIKADO LOGO 800 XXTREME FBL
From Mikado Model Helicopters this is the Logo 800 Xxtreme. This is a graceful 800 size electric Flybarless heli in real life and in the sim.
This model is purpose built for RealFlight 6 and up. Upgrade to enjoy


Special thanks to Kyle Stacey for his input for the final physics setup.
Special thanks to Jeffrey Johnson for providing super high quality pictures of his 800 Xxtreme.
Special Thanks to Kyle Dahl for quality pictures of his 800 Xxtreme.

Features custom Edge 813mm main blades and 115mm tail blades equipped for night flying.
The model itself is also night flying equipped.
Animated motor helps complete the illusion





Enjoy

After a long Mapping session lasting around 8 hours. I have all of the original parts mapped. Not including the Vbar system I just modeled. I have optimized as far as this model can take to be able to put in some of the electronics. After modeling the Vbar I have 686 polys left for a receiver pack and some wires, but not all. For those that don't like math polys are at 19,314.
I guess that means you won't have enough polys left to do the slots in the front of the canopy . Nevertheless good work!

I plan on doing the slots in the CS. I've seen a Xxtreme with mesh covering the slots from the inside. That's what I will replicate. The trick is that I will do a render in max from the front of the heli with the canopy off. Then use that render to fill the slots then cover with a mesh texture. The result should be nice looking. Don't worry someone will complain about wires missing or head speed sensor or whatever. Its all about concessions with this big bird.

Whats that all about that you used my Sound Profile? Please remove it from the file, I could not remember you asked for it. Thank you!

Groni, any component of a file that is posted here can be used in another file, historically.  Once you post a model that uses a sound profile, blade, prop, battery, engine (those 2 are defined in the RF editor), etc., it's available for others to use.  How am I to know whether a battery I picked is one you designed?  It's not delineated in the editor like that.  The only unacceptable thing to do is for someone to post an EA when he didn't build the 3D model.  That's the way it's always been.  Otherwise, a sound profile is a sound profile, and if I have it available, I may use it.  If you don't want others to use it, don't post it.

I think you know I can't remove the file after child files have been made. I guess I assumed that since I allowed you to use my physics as a basis for your 630 you would return the courtesy. To tell you the truth I don't even remember applying the sound profile. I won't use it in the future. Sorry

name: Heli MAX 1SQ QuadCopter_EA
description:
This model requires the latest beta update 6.50.016 The orange and black blades needed for this model come with the new update.
The new model found in the latest beta is also a 1SQ. It is purely coincidental.


Heli-Max 1SQ quadcopter.
This is a micro quad with the stability of a much larger quadcopter. The TAGs™ (Triple Axis Gyro Stabilaization) is behind the solid stability of this fun little quad. Low weight (1.2oz AUW) and quality construction make for a very durable model.

I own this model personally and this RF model flys just like the real thing.
Low rates will give the real life flight behavior, but you can flip the dual rates switch to allow for flips and higher speed.


Features:
Canopy release on channel6(knob)
High rates for more extreme maneuvers.

Enjoy!





Enjoy

name: Compass Warp360_EA
description:
Compass Models Warp 360
The Compass Warp 360 is the newest helicopter to the Compass Model product line. The Warp 360 is a low-maintenance, aggressive, powerful and quiet 450 size electric helicopter!
The Compass Warp 360 utilizes a single-stage direct belt drive which allows for an extremely quiet and efficient drive-train. The rotor head is comprised of a nearly rigid design by Compass Model. This head design provides a level of precision and aggressive response more commonly associated with the larger 90 size electrics, to the 450 size market.


Thanks to the designer of the Compass Models Warp 360 Sebastian Zajonz
Special thanks to Sebastia Serra for his help in tuning the physics.






Enjoy

threadData.body: This is the first of two helis from Compass models I will be modeling. This one is the Warp 360. It's a 450 class heli. There are a lot of carbon fiber parts on this one and the design overall is pretty unique. I have this model in hand so I have all the reference I need. This is today's progress and polys are at 4,676.
I will be following the warp with the Compass Models 7HV FBL V2.
Here is more progress on the Warp 360. Most of the work is between the blade holders and the Main gear. Polys are at 8656 including the canopy seen in the other shots.

Looking good Boof as usual.

You have this model?? It has a interesting head setup on that heli. No dampeners or feathering shafts from what I read about it.
Yes I have this one. I'm building it as I build this model. The feathering is supposed to be the job of the CF grips.
Push a pixel, glue a part!!
Yeah. More like screw a part, but yeah.
Screw, glue, what's the difference?
Not much I guess. You just don't have to wait for screws to dry.
Little more progress. Polys are at 10,838.
KE should hire you. You do as good or better work than they do. (You'd get paid, and you wouldn't have a poly limit!! )
Thanks Jeff. That's the old dream I had a few months after I started modeling for the sim. Now all I want are more polys.

I put a few more hours in today with some good results. I decided the large hole in the side frames over the tail block were to noticeable a detail to trust to the bump map. I modeled most of the tail. I don't have any push rods done yet, but the servos are in they are modeled after the MKS DS95 micros. I enjoyed doing the drive train. The belts look nice to me. I still need Electronics. Battery, FBL unit (MicroBeastX), reciever, and ESC. Hopefully I can model the wiring too. This is were another 5k polys would be really handy. Also needed still are blur discs and coll mesh. Polys are at 13,635 with the whole model optimized as I go.
You should remove all faces that will never be visible.  That will help your poly count.
Oh ok. I'll try that.
Looking good as usual. I have to agree with Jeff. KE, GIVE THIS MAN A SALARY!
Haha! Thanks Andy.

More work on the Warp after helping someone move all day. All push rods are modeled, battery w/straps, microbeastX, and BEC. I still have blur discs, coll mesh, and wires to do. I just noticed I need to model velcro between the battery and the tray. Triangles are at 16,096.
Awesome work my friend! You're doing it really fast hehe.
Modeling is more accurate and fast when the model is sitting in front of you.

Thanks guys. It is coming together fairly quickly but I haven't been able to work on it every day. Things always slow down once the mapping starts. I have finished the real build except the electronics which I haven't purchased yet. I have discovered a great poly saving technique for cylinder objects with varying diameters or extrusions . It has helped the poly count quite a bit on this model. I will most likely make a tip or a vid covering the idea. It is very useful for helis simply because they tend to be cylinder heavy.

It's getting closer. I have the coll mesh done and the blur discs. The wiring has a good start. I would like to add a BEC to the mix. Triangles are at 18,821. This one will have all the details I usually would like to add to the helis I do.

The CS is getting very close to being finished. I still have some tweaking to do with the physics as well. This is what I have after tonight's CS session.

Aside from maybe a tweak or two the CS is done. I wanted the belts, which of course are static, to look as if they are moving. The belts have writing on them but while in motion the text turns into long lines so I replicated that. It still needed something more so I moved a few of the edges on the main gear just outside of the belt. As the main gear spins these edges break up the white lines and really help to create the illusion the belt is moving. Screenshots can't convey the effect but the black vertical lines in the belt are the main gear edges. Overall I'm happy with the end result. Now I just need to get the physics tuned in.

Thanks N8LBV. I never did plan on flying the real one it was on loan to build the model. The physics were tested by a Compass models sponsored pilot and he never mentioned a problem with the tail. If you would like a faster tail there a few ways to accomplish that. This is one: Change the "Rotation Rate (deg/sec)" parameter in the editor. You will find it in Electronics/Electronic Flybar/Yaw. It is currently set to 720° per second. Increasing this value will give faster rotation.
